Because...

(1) even your small test crawl of the source URI misses the target URIs 
listed on that page, and

(2) the target URIs appear in no logs


...we can be relatively certain the issue is that something in your 
scope is preventing them from being enqueued-for-collection.

With that, I looked over the URIs and scope rules closely and see the 
problem:

These URIs...

> http://www.mrt.ac.lk/web/sites/all/themes/nucleus/nucleus/nucleus/css/base.css?mupdwq
> http://www.mrt.ac.lk/web/sites/all/themes/nucleus/nucleus/nucleus/css/messages.css?mupdwq
> http://www.mrt.ac.lk/web/sites/all/themes/nucleus/nucleus/nucleus/js/jquery.cookie.js?mupdwq

...will all be rejected by the scope rule...

>      <!-- ...and REJECT those with suspicious repeating path-segments... -->
>      <bean
> class="org.archive.modules.deciderules.PathologicalPathDecideRule">
>       <!-- <property name="maxRepetitions" value="2" /> -->
>      </bean>

...because of the repeating "/nucleus/nucleus/nucleus/" portion of the 
URI: more than 2 repeated path-segments.

This is a default rule because such URI patterns are very often an 
indicator of an endless crawler-trap expanding-URI path. So, the rule 
often saves the crawler from endless crawloing of meaningless/repetitive 
content. But, all the default rules are just based on fuzzy guesswork 
about what's most often useful, and specific sites (like yours) may 
deviate. (The default maxPathHops of 20 is a similar fuzzy heuristic: 
it's rare for valuable URIs to have more than 20 path-segments... but 
some sites might, and in such cases, you'd want to change your settings.)

Your options would be to either remove the PathologicalPathDecideRule, 
or allow more than 2 repeated path-segments before treating a URI as 
deserving a REJECT decision. Of course, that would increase the risk 
your crawl follows certain trap paths, so you'd want to watch your logs 
and run-times for that.

If, after suspecting the scope, it wasn't immediately clear what rule 
was to blame, then the next debugging step would usually be to study the 
effects of each rule in sequence, as each discovered URI was considered. 
As a developer, and once knowing exactly what source page is implicated, 
I'd often do this inside a debugger, stepping through the code as each 
source URI outlink was evaluated. But another option is the suggestion 
that Noah made on Dec-11 in response to your question about "best 
max-hop count" - you can force a DecideRuleSequence to 'logToFile' scope 
decisions, which can help identify which rules aren't behaving as you 
expect.

- Gordon
